azcentral.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of the Arizona Republic, providing original news and perspectives on Phoenix, surrounding communities and the state of Arizona. Azcentral.com is part of the USA Today Network.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site and the USA Today Network are owned by Gannett, a publicly traded media company, which owns more than 100 news organizations including the flagship USA Today. The site’s revenue comes from advertising and subscriptions. Users are charged for access to the site after they read a limited number of free articles a month. 

Content

Like other websites in the USA Today Network, the site presents local news, sports, entertainment and opinion in a format similar to the USA Today flagship site. Opinion columnists, who most often write about local politics, schools, and immigration, are prominently featured.

The AZ Fact Check section looks at the veracity of statements related to local news, such as the Pulitzer Prize-winning series on the proposed U.S.-Mexico border wall. Reports in that section are prominently featured with videos.

Users can find tabs for national and international news on azcentral.com, content produced by USA Today, and Network news sites.

The Arizona Republic’s most frequently endorses conservative candidates and causes. It typically supports Republicans for national office. However, the Republic endorsed Hillary Clinton for president in 2016, the first time in its history it supported a Democratic presidential candidate.

Credibility

Headlines and graphics accurately describe related stories. News reporting, headlines, and story selections are balanced and fact-based.

Arizona Republic and the USA Today Network won a Scripps Howard award for innovation, and a Pulitzer Prize for explanatory journalism in 2017, for their reporting on President Donald Trump’s proposed border wall. The publication has won two other Pulitzers for editorial cartooning and numerous awards from the Arizona Newspapers Association.

The site invites readers  to correct errors they find on the site, providing an email address and instructions. It also explains that it adheres to the USA Today Network’s ethical principles, which call for correcting errors promptly, and the site regularly corrects errors.

Transparency

A staff directory provides photos, emails and social media contacts for news staff, and phone numbers for many. A link to Republic Media refers to the executive team for the local publications.

The site identifies itself as part of the USA Today Network.  Most stories are attributed to their authors, and the bylines indicate if the reporter is local, from the USA Today staff or has another affiliation. Ads are clearly labeled.

History

The Arizona Republican began publishing in 1890, shortening its name to the Arizona Republic in 1930. The site domain was registered in 1995.
